entity1.name: Ancient Egypt
entity1.description: Structures or rooms where the dead are buried, often containing items for use in the afterlife.;;;A historical region in northeastern Africa, known for its ancient civilization and monuments.;;;A civilization in northeastern Africa, known for its advanced culture and significant historical contributions.;;;A historical region in northeastern Africa, known for its advanced civilization and monumental architecture.;;;Structures or chambers used for the burial of the dead, often containing artifacts and inscriptions.;;;Burial places in ancient Egypt where the dead were laid to rest, often containing items and texts for use in the afterlife.;;;A room or space within a tomb where the deceased is laid to rest, often containing items intended for use in the afterlife.
entity1.chunkid: Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices6;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices17;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices1;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices13;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices14;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices19;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices22

entity2.name: Egyptians
entity2.description: An ancient civilization that inhabited the Nile Valley and developed a complex society with advanced architecture, art, and religious practices.;;;A method of preserving bodies through the removal of moisture to prevent decay, commonly practiced in ancient Egypt.;;;The customs and rituals associated with funerals and burials in ancient Egyptian society, which included mummification among other procedures.;;;The customs and rituals associated with the preparation and interment of the dead in ancient Egypt, reflecting beliefs about the afterlife.;;;A group of people from ancient Egypt, known for their cultural and architectural contributions.;;;A civilization that inhabited the Nile Valley in northeastern Africa from around 3100 BCE to the conquest by Alexander the Great in 332 BCE.;;;The method of preserving bodies through dehydration and embalming, typically associated with ancient Egyptian culture.;;;An ancient civilization that inhabited the region along the Nile River in northeastern Africa.;;;A process used by ancient Egyptians to preserve bodies for the afterlife, involving embalming and drying the body to prevent decay.;;;The inhabitants of Egypt, particularly those from the ancient period who developed a complex society and culture.;;;The cultural practices and beliefs of ancient Egypt, including religious rituals and customs.;;;A group of people from ancient Egypt, known for their advanced civilization and contributions to art, architecture, and religion.;;;A method of preserving a body to prevent decay and ensure its preservation for the afterlife, often associated with ancient Egyptian practices.;;;The people who inhabited or are descended from those who inhabited the Nile Valley and delta, primarily in what is now the country of Egypt.;;;The customs and rituals associated with the preparation and interment of the dead in ancient Egypt.;;;The collective customs, arts, social institutions, and achievements that characterize Egyptian society throughout its history.

entity3.name: afterlife
entity3.description: The existence or state of being that is believed to occur after death, according to various religious and cultural beliefs.;;;The belief in a form of existence or consciousness that continues after the death of the physical body, particularly significant in ancient Egyptian culture.;;;A belief in life after death, which was central to Ancient Egyptian religious practices and influenced their burial customs.;;;The belief in life after death, particularly in ancient Egyptian religion, where the soul of the deceased continues to exist and may travel to a different realm or world.;;;A belief in the existence of a life after death, prevalent in ancient Egyptian religion.;;;The belief in a form of existence or consciousness that continues after physical death, as held by ancient Egyptians.;;;A term referring to the belief that a part of an individual's essence continues to exist after death, as held by ancient Egyptians.;;;The belief in life or existence after physical death, common in many religions and cultures.;;;The belief or concept that some part of an individual's identity or consciousness continues after physical death.;;;A term used to describe the continuation of existence after death, as believed by various cultures and religions.;;;A term used to describe the continuation of existence after death, as believed in various cultures and religions.;;;The existence or state believed to occur after death, often associated with a realm beyond the physical world.;;;A belief in life after death, which was an integral part of ancient Egyptian religion and culture.;;;The belief in life or existence after death, particularly in cultures that practice mummification.

entity7.name: pyramids at Giza
entity7.description: Large structures built in ancient Egypt as tombs for pharaohs and their consorts.;;;Large structures built as tombs for Egyptian pharaohs, designed to protect the deceased's body and possessions and to serve as a gateway to the afterlife.;;;A group of monumental structures located on the Giza Plateau, which served as tombs for pharaohs and their consorts in ancient Egypt.
entity7.chunkid: Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices5;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices3;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices20

entity8.name: pharaohs
entity8.description: Ancient Egyptian rulers who were considered both political and religious leaders.

entity12.name: deceased
entity12.description: A person who has died and is being referred to in the context of burial practices.

entity20.name: internal organs
entity20.description: The internal parts of the body, such as the heart, liver, and lungs.

entity21.name: salt
entity21.description: A mineral composed primarily of sodium chloride, commonly used for seasoning and preserving food.

entity22.name: linen bandages
entity22.description: Cloth strips made from flax or cotton, often used in the process of mummification to wrap a body.

entity24.name: soul
entity24.description: A non-physical essence of a living being, often considered immortal and separable from the body after death.

entity30.name: Book of the Dead
entity30.description: An ancient Egyptian funerary text used to guide souls through the afterlife, consisting of spells, hymns, and instructions.;;;An ancient Egyptian funerary text, used to assist a deceased person's journey to the afterlife.
entity30.chunkid: Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices14;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices16

entity31.name: spells and prayers
entity31.description: A collection of magical incantations and religious invocations used in ancient rituals.

entity33.name: realm of the gods
entity33.description: A divine place in mythology where deities are thought to reside and rule over various aspects of existence.

entity35.name: papyrus scrolls
entity35.description: A material made from papyrus plants, commonly used in ancient Egypt for writing and inscriptions.

entity37.name: priests
entity37.description: Religious leaders or officials who perform religious duties and rituals.

entity38.name: embalmers
entity38.description: Specialized workers responsible for the preservation of bodies through mummification processes.

entity39.name: The deceased's family
entity39.description: A group of people related by blood or marriage, who are mourning the loss of a member.

entity40.name: professional mourners
entity40.description: Individuals hired to perform mourning rituals and lead funeral processions as part of their job.

entity42.name: elite
entity42.description: The upper class or ruling class of a society, often characterized by wealth, power, and privilege.

entity43.name: common people
entity43.description: The general population of a society, typically not part of the elite or ruling classes.

entity52.name: religious texts
entity52.description: Written documents or inscriptions that hold religious significance, often used in funerary contexts to guide the deceased.

entity53.name: amulets
entity53.description: Small objects believed to have magical properties, often placed with the dead for protection or guidance in the afterlife.

entity55.name: gods
entity55.description: Supernatural beings worshipped by the ancient Egyptians, believed to have control over natural and human phenomena.;;;Supernatural beings worshipped as part of a religion or belief system, often associated with natural phenomena or aspects of life.
entity55.chunkid: Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices22;;;Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices25

entity58.name: society
entity58.description: The aggregate of people living together in a more or less ordered community, specifically referring to the social organization of ancient Egypt.
